Topic.Title: YHOO has a very bearish chart. Absolutely horrible if you are long

Message.Msg: Easier money going long on GOOG and AIG. Both have insanely bullish charts. Call options on either are making boatloads of cash for me and others. My short position on YHOO is small at this point. Too much easier playing other stocks. I knew there were too many peole calling a top in this market. Also CNBC guys saying GOOG down back to 700 but chart showed earning rally held and diminishing volume after the spike to 760 and price holding was a coiled spring and boy did that spring spring into fresh new high territory. GOOG glory days are back and I'm going to ride it while it lasts. AIG is poised for a continued long term run higher. YHOO too boring at this point. Good luck waiting on the Alibaba and Yahoo Japan stuff. I'm going where the profitss are happening NOW!

Message.Title: Apple/Microsoft Growth and Competitive Challenges
Message.Msg: Apple and Microsoft are growing earnings at slower than historical rates, and are getting pounded by the other giants- Google, Facebook, and Samsung. To improve their market positions, they need to do something big, and YHOO looks like a logical extension to Apple and Microsoft's core businesses. YHOO can be acquired cheaply at around $31 (Same level MSFT originally offered) exactly 5 years ago. Apple or MSFT could sell off the approximately $15/share value of Alibaba and Yahoo Japan and keep the media and mobile pieces of YHOO that are the growth pieces. Seems like a no brainer that YHOO will eventually be acquired by one of these cash rich companies. Microsoft Proposes Acquisition of Yahoo! for $31 per Share Feb. 01, 2008 Transaction valued at approximately $44.6 billion in cash and stock; provides 62 percent premium to current trading price for Yahoo! shareholders; combined entity to create a more competitive company, providing superior value to shareholders, better choice and innovation for customers and partners

Topic.Title: FMR LLC also began accumulating as of its last 13F filing . . .

Topic.Title: Apple/Microsoft Growth and Competitive Challenges

Message.Msg: Microsoft’s consistent belief has been that the combination of Microsoft and Yahoo! clearly represents the best way to deliver maximum value to our respective shareholders, as well as create a more efficient and competitive company that would provide greater value and service to our customers. In late 2006 and early 2007, we jointly explored a broad range of ways in which our two companies might work together. These discussions were based on a vision that the online businesses of Microsoft and Yahoo! should be aligned in some way to create a more effective competitor in the online marketplace. We discussed a number of alternatives ranging from commercial partnerships to a merger proposal, which you rejected. While a commercial partnership may have made sense at one time, Microsoft believes that the only alternative now is the combination of Microsoft and Yahoo! that we are proposing. In February 2007, I received a letter from your Chairman indicating the view of the Yahoo! Board that “now is not the right time from the perspective of our shareholders to enter into discussions regarding an acquisition transaction.” According to that letter, the principal reason for this view was the Yahoo! Board’s confidence in the “potential upside” if management successfully executed on a reformulated strategy based on certain operational initiatives, such as Project Panama, and a significant organizational realignment. A year has gone by, and the competitive situation has not improved.

Topic.Title: Third Point owns 63 million shares of Yahoo

Message.Msg: LMAO that honestly doesn't make any sense. If Yahoo had 10 shares outstanding and you owned 6 of them knowing you had Yahoo willing to pay any price to buy them back are you going to sell or wait until it goes sky high? Now if he said it was to rebalance his portfolio that is fine but to say its cause of Yahoo's buyback is B.S. Don't you think you would have learned ANYTHING when volume sky-rocketed and Icahn gave Bartz a vote of confidence only to SELL out completely by that March, years ago. Excuses are like a'holes everyone has one! Dumping 11M shares is not "rebalancing"! How does a buyback removing 6% of shares make a guy dump almost 20% of his position anyway?

Topic.Title: Buy or sell Yahoo at $20?

Topic.Title: Third Point owns 63 million shares of Yahoo

Message.Msg: "Loeb sold to maintain his percentage stake in Yahoo adjusted for Yahoo's buybacks. Yahoo will keep climbing as they buyback another $1.5B in stock this quarter." So Yahoo buys back about 6.5% of the outstanding shares and Third Point/Loeb cuts his stake by 15% and that somehow maintains his percentage stake in Yahoo adjusted for buybacks? Now perhaps he sold 15% in anticipation of the additional buybacks. However if that is the case, he must feel there is limited upside or he would have only sold 6%-7% now and more later as perhaps the price appreciated. To me, selling as much as he did tells me he think there is limited upside from here. Not that it is going down, but at a minimum, the upside is somewhat limited. One other thing to ponder, as a memeber of the Board of Directors, he would perhaps have knowledge of any pending partnerships, buyouts, deals, on and on. So if there was any big news coming anytime soon like so many on this board wish for, I think his action here put those to rest, at least for the time being. Remember, he didn't have to do anything if in fact news was coming. But the fact he sold 11 million shares I think lays to rest for a while the lilkeyhood of any major news coming. So all those posters on here on hopium expecting news any moment to send this stock higher, I think ThirdPoint/Loeb just tossed cold water on your dreams. JMHO
